[BIOIN-1448] Implemented filtering of VCF that changes GQ/GT/PL (#160)

This PR updates the way we are filtering GATK VCFs. Until now we trained the filtering models using approximate ground truths. This allows marking the variant as True/False but not changing the genotype.

In this PR I am adding the ability to use a model that is trained on the exact ground truth and in this case it is possible to not only filter the variant but also change the genotype. The model works (similar to the DeepVariant) by predicting genotype one of the three possible genotypes: hom-ref, hom-alt and het-alt.

The main challenge that also required some code work was applying the model to multiallelic variants. The heuristic that I chose for the multiallelic variants: R,A1,A2 (the first one is the reference).

Pick the "strongest" allele (e.g. A1),
Combine the support for A1 and A2 into a single allele A
Genotype (R,A): the result is (PL'(R,R), PL'(R,A), PL'(A,A))
Genotype (A1,A2), where A1 is the reference, A2 is the "alt".
Merge the support in the following way to generate PL(R,R),PL(R,A1),PL(A1,A1),PL(R,A2),PL(A1,A2),PL(A2,A2) tuple
PL(R,R) = PL'(R,R)
PL(R,A1) = PL'(R,A)
PL(A1,A1) = PL'(A,A) * PL'(A1,A1)
PL(A1,A2) = PL'(A,A) * PL(A1,A2)
PL(A2,A2) = PL(A,A) * PL(A2,A2)

Note that PL(R,A2) is zero here. 

This logic is implemented in the function `variant_filtering_utils.combine_multiallelic_spandel`

There are two main files to review, everything else is not really important (cosmetics)

BIOIN-1558 srsnv cv by chromosome (#167)

Overview
This PR adds support for training SRSNV model with a cross-validation (CV) scheme. CV is needed when SRSNV inference is used on the same featuremaps used for training, because without CV there's a danger of overfitting.

How to use
To use CV, need to set the new parameter num_CV_folds to the number of folds required. By default, this is 1, i.e., no CV (regular train-test split). Each read in the training featuremap dataframe is assigned a fold, stored in the fold_id column. Model k associated with fold k is trained on all data where fold_id != k, and validated on fold_id == k. By default, folds are split by chromosome, to make sure there is no leakage between training and validation sets (fold_id's can be assigned randomly by setting split_folds_by to random rather than chrom. With random fold-splitting, at inference time an ensemble of all num_CV_folds models is used for inference).

fold_id can have one of 3 types of values.

A number k in 0, 1, ..., num_CV_folds-1. These reads are in the training set of all models except model k.
-1. These reads are in the training set when num_CV_folds==1, i.e., when using regular train-test split. The test set reads in this case have fold_id=0.
np.nan. These reads are not included in any training set, and so (an ensemble of) all models can be used for inference.
The new function k_fold_predict_proba can be used to evaluate the trained models on a dataset (it accepts a list of models, a dataset, and the name of the column containing fold_ids, and evaluates the models according to these rules.

Other changes in this PR
Categorical features are defined together with all possible values, ensuring that they are consistently encoded by the model during training, validation, and inference.
Models are saved in a joblib file that contains relevant meta-data, like the parameters used in training (which include the mapping of chromosomes to folds, and the details of all categorical variables), and also the interpolating function that maps ML_qual to SNVQ.
Hyperparameters were changes to include more training rounds and use early-stopping to reduce overfitting.
Small bug fixes, including in the calculation of the residual snv rate.
